elements.name: MedicalPanel
elements.description:
Under BC Law, a child under the age of 19 may consent to their own health care – if they understand the details of the treatment including the risks and benefits and the health treatment has been determined to be in their best interests. For more information on the Infants Act, visit BC Laws.

When a minor does not have the capacity to consent, the consent of the child’s guardian is required. Normally, the guardian will instruct the medical, dental or other health care provider and give or refuse consent on behalf of the child.

Subject to s. 17 of the Infants Act, the parental responsibility of giving, refusing or withdrawing consent to medical, dental or other health-related treatments for the child may be allocated to one or more of the child’s guardians under an agreement or court order.

elements.name: delayRisk
elements.title: Will a delay of the medical, dental or other health-related treatment or court decision result in a risk to the child’s health?

elements.name: FAQLegalAdvice
elements.title: I’m not sure. Where can I get legal assistance?
elements.body:
Understanding the law and making sure you get correct information is important. If you get the wrong information or do not know how the law applies to your situation, it can be harder to resolve your case. Getting advice from a lawyer can help.

Lawyers: To find a lawyer or to have a free consultation with a lawyer for up to 30 minutes, contact the Lawyer Referral Service at 1-800-663-1919

Legal Aid, Duty Counsel and Family Advice Lawyers: To find out if you qualify for free legal advice or representation, contact Legal Aid BC at

1-866-577-2525.



Legal Services and Resources: Visit Clicklaw at www.clicklaw.bc.ca/helpmap to find other free and low-cost legal services in your community

elements.name: confirmRisk
elements.title: Please confirm you are applying for an order about a priority parenting matter because a guardian has given, refused or withdrawn consent to medical, dental or other health-related treatment for a child and delay will result in risk to the child’s health.
choices: I want to apply for this order about a priority parenting matter.

elements.name: yesDelayRiskInfo
elements.title: If you do not want to apply for this order as a priority parenting matter, you can apply for an order about parenting arrangements including the allocation of parental responsibilities by selecting family law matter on the first step in this service. Remember to de-select priority parenting matter. The court can allocate parental responsibilities including that consent of only one guardian is required for these decisions about a child.

elements.name: noDelayRiskInfo
elements.title: This is a priority parenting matter only if a delay will result in risk to the child’s health. If you require an order about a health-related decision for a child, but it is not a priority parenting matter, you can apply for an order about parenting arrangements by selecting family law matter on the first step in this service. Remember to de-select priority parenting matter.
